dt: {bc}to soil, stain, corrupt, or infect by {a_link|contact} or association
{bc}to make inferior or impure by admixture
{bc}to make unfit for use by the introduction of unwholesome or undesirable elements

pt: {sc}contaminate{/sc} {sc}taint{/sc} {sc}pollute{/sc} {sc}defile{/sc} mean to make impure or unclean. {sc}contaminate{/sc} implies intrusion of or contact with dirt or foulness from an outside source.
{sc}taint{/sc} stresses the loss of purity or cleanliness that follows contamination.

{sc}pollute{/sc}, sometimes interchangeable with {it}contaminate{/it}, distinctively may imply that the process which begins with contamination is complete and that what was pure or clean has been made foul, poisoned, or filthy.
{sc}defile{/sc} implies befouling of what could or should have been kept clean and pure or held sacred and commonly suggests violation or desecration.

pt.t: {it}defile{/it} a hero's memory with slanderous innuendo

et: Middle English {it}contaminaten,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}contāminātus,{/it} past participle of {it}contāmināre{/it} "to defile, pollute," from {it}con-{/it} {et_link|con-|com-} + {it}-tāmināre,{/it} verbal derivative of {it}*tāmen{/it} "touching, contact," going back to {it}*tāg-(s)men,{/it} from {it}tag-,{/it} variant stem of {it}tangere{/it} "to touch" + {it}*-(s)men,{/it} noun suffix of result {ma}{mat|tangent:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: to soil, stain, corrupt, or infect by contact or association
to make inferior or impure by admixture
to make unfit for use by the introduction of unwholesome or undesirable elements

dt: {bc}inadvertent transfer of bacteria or other contaminants from one surface, substance, etc., to another especially because of unsanitary handling procedures

dt.t: With raw eggs, as with raw chickens, it is important to avoid {wi}cross contamination{/wi}. Use separate utensils—bowls, forks, knives, counter tops, and cutting boards—for raw chickens or eggs, and clean them thoroughly before reusing them for cooked foods.

Jim Steinhoff, a sanitarian and food inspector for the La Crosse County Health Department, said {wi}cross-contamination{/wi} is the cause of the recent nationwide salmonella outbreak with peanut butter products.

utxt.t: "ARB {gloss}=antibiotic-resistant bacteria{/gloss} are carried into the kitchen on contaminated meat and poultry, where other foods are {wi}cross-contaminated{/wi} because of common unsafe handling practices."

There's an ongoing debate about whether wood or plastic is more bacteria-resistant. But more important than the material of your cutting board is how you clean it. Don't {wi}cross-contaminate{/wi} it by using an old sponge or less-than-pristine dishtowel.

shortdef: inadvertent transfer of bacteria or other contaminants from one surface, substance, etc., to another especially because of unsanitary handling procedures
